name: Scylla
desc: The Prince of Vishaps and Remus's friend.

Dragon King
Prince of Vishaps
Vishap-Prince
Dragon Prince

customize.text: The Rise and Fall of Remuria

<color=#ffffff73>In the realm where the Primordial Waters yet surged, the Mistress of Many Waters, Egeria, was imprisoned by the Heavens for committing the original sin. Scylla, the Prince of Vishaps, was prince over the Dragonborn in the distant past but now guarded the prison of Egeria. There, in the Fontemer, Scylla encountered Remus, the God King of Remuria. A battle ensued between Vishaps and Remus's Golden fleet for the thirty-day battle upon their meeting. It was only when exhaustion bought respite that the God King used music to voice his purpose. As the prophecy foretold that the endless waves would swallow his nation, he sought an audience with Egeria, hoping that she may have answers.</color>
<color=#ffffff73>Scylla laughed upon hearing his ridiculous goals:</color>

<color=#ffffffd9>"Usurper-lord of mortals, you fear the senseless curse, and excoriate the chains of fate, but know not that my kind has suffered agony a hundred times yet greater. We have lost our soil and sunlight, and we now may only exist in the lightless abyssal depths. Usurper-lord of mortals, surely you know that fate is the rite of the high heavens, and cannot be changed even in the slightest. To have this thought is tantamount to revolt against that authority. But if you truly wish to plot such folly, then I shall take you to see the Mistress of Many Waters."</color>

<color=#ffffff73>Remus learned every terrifying secret â€” yet he found no answer leading to salvation. In the end, this king who still harbored ambition and hope decided to take a cup of the purest water before leaving, and promised Egeria he would use the pure water she granted him to create a world of endless prosperity and peace. Scylla followed Remus to the surface, driven by a desire to witness that promised future. They formed a friendship that would surpass even Remuria's downfall.</color>

<color=#ffffff73>One day, the God King Remus awoke to the sound of terror and remorse due to violence and estrangement that had arisen between the Remurians and Fontainians. He realized that the Grand</color>
<color=#ffffff73>he created led the empire to its downfall and decided to destroy it. The God King called out to Scylla and made an arrangement that granted the power of his Final Symphony, Requiem, unto him so that Phobos could be destroyed. Scylla had to lead an army of Dragonborn to Machimos to breach the inner city, Capitolium, where the God King Remus resided. Boethius, one of Remus's four Harmosts and a conductor of the Symphony, discovered Remus's plan and devised an inescapable trap to lure Scylla. He falsely claimed to have surrendered on Remus's orders, stating that the God King had commanded the legions to cease resistance.</color>

<color=#ffffff73>Three chains were forged of the exalted Harmost Euergetia's blood and unknown bone. The chains were moved to Caesareum Palace and were to be used to imprison Scylla. When Scylla arrived with his Vishap army, Boethius unexpectedly turned against him. Machimos, the outer city of Remuria's capital, was separated from Capitolium by a barrier known as the Initium Iani, which the Vishap-Prince needed to pass through to enter the inner city. The Symphony woven by the God King Remus and his musicians, which encompassed all of Remuria, passed through the barrier. The Harmost and his legions exploited this and shut the gates, thus stopping Scylla and his army. With the three chains in place, he was left immobilized and he could not make it to Domus Aurea in time to complete Remus's final order. His flesh and blood turned to stone, the waves devoured the whole city, and his kindred could not escape. Although Scylla's original body was destroyed, his memories in the Ichor continued to live, but he still remained sealed within the ruins of Machimos.</color>
<color=#ffffff73>The remnants of the golem army continued to fight the descendants of the dragons. The last of the Remurians, and the lone descendant of the dragon, eventually reached a peace agreement. Some say both betrayed their homelands and built new settlements for exiles. As for what really happened in the stillness beneath the ocean depths, it has been interpreted and re-interpreted by countless operas.</color>
<color=#ffd780>Related Entries:</color>

customize.name: Egeria
customize.desc: The previous Hydro Archon who died during the Cataclysm 500 years ago.

customize.name: Song of Stillness
customize.desc: A strange longbow that resembles a sea creature. Its string makes no sound at all.

customize.name: The History of the Decline and Fall of Remuria

customize.text: <color=#ffffff73>It was not until Boethius enacted a plan to bring back Remuria that Scylla was able to be freed from his confinement. Boethius had gained mastery over the Symphony and filled the bodies of the people of Petrichor with the souls of the long-dead Remurians. In order to save the people of Petrichor, another Harmost, Cassiodor, turned to the Traveler and Paimon for help. Together, they entered the Sea of Bygone Eras and broke the chains that bound Scylla, freeing him. Cassiodor was not at the capital when Scylla first arrived all those years ago. Due to this, he believed that Vishap-prince had betrayed the God King and attacked the Golden Palace, causing Remuria to be flooded. The Prince of Vishaps revealed the arrangement between him and Remus, their secret plan, and the creation of the Requiem, which was an order for the Grand Symphony to self-destruct. Destroying the Symphony was how the God King planned to free his subjects from their stone bodies and give them back forms of flesh and blood, destroying the artificial barrier between races. Remus was to sacrifice himself to unleash the Symphony's power, and it would fall to Scylla to control the primordial, savage energies that he would awaken. Scylla had led an army of Vishaps to assault the capital as part of Remus's final plan to save the Remurians and the nation by destroying the Grand Symphony.</color>

<color=#ffffff73>Although Scylla wanted to help defeat Boethius, he was concerned that this could give the Harmost the opportunity to seize the Final Symphony that had been entrusted to him. The Dragon Prince also felt he could not help in the fight against Boethius, as he was merely a temporary occupant of an Ichor-made body. The chief strength of Dragonborn lay in their powerful flesh, embedded in Ichor as he is, all that remains of him is the feeblest of wills. Although he had lost his bodily form, he could still command the currents. Scylla roamed the ocean depths and used the currents to help aid the Traveler in the Sea of Bygone Eras.</color>

<color=#ffffff73>With Scylla's help, the Traveler and Paimon reconnected the golden aqueducts, through which the Grand Symphony once flowed, and opened the way to the Golden Palace. The Dragon Prince bestowed the Requiem unto the Traveler, and once played, the Grand Symphony was completely destroyed, and the souls of the Remurians returned to the deep waters, to the eternal cycle of life and death. After finally fulfilling Remus's wish, Scylla brought Traveler and Paimon back to the surface. He shared his plans to seek an audience with the true Hydro Dragon, Neuvillette, as a Dragon Sovereign could not be reborn while Egeria was imprisoned in the Primordial Sea.</color>
<color=#ffd780>Related Entries:</color>

customize.name: Nostoi Region
customize.desc: In the ancient language, Petrichor means "golem." Now it is a run-down fishing village on a small island far away from Fontaine's waters.

customize.name: Sea of Bygone Eras
customize.desc:
The wide waters that lie south of the Great Terrestrial Lake were also once an integral part of that high sea. Beneath the abyssal depths untouched by sunlight, the first of dreams and hopes lie buried.

The long-forgotten symphony sounds once more amidst the stronghold of dimmed glories and the sea-sunken ruins. A new chapter in a tale long-ended is about to be written...
